awd_titl_txt: RUI: Collaborative Research: Intrinsic Gas-phase Properties of Peptides: Thermochemistry, Fragmentation Mechanisms, H/D exchange and IRMPD Spectroscopy.
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms program is supporting the collaborative research of Professor John C. Poutsma at the College of William and Mary and Professor Jennifer Poutsma at Old Dominion University. Professor John Poutsma employs mass spectrometry-based experiments to study the subtle interplay between the structure of peptides and their gas-phase energetic properties. He studies peptides containing non-protein amino acids (NPAA), which are found naturally in plants and fungi, but are not used in natural protein synthesis. Many NPAAs are toxic to humans and other animals in part due to structural similarity to one or more of the twenty common protein amino acids (PAA). NPAAs can compete with PAAs in a variety of biological pathways including being mis-incorporated into proteins and peptides. Studying the behavior of peptides into which NPAAs have been systematically substituted helps to understand the relationship between a peptide's structure and its behavior in the mass spectrometer. Ultimately this enhanced understanding may lead to improved automated peptide sequencing algorithms for proteomics experiments. Professor Jennifer Poutsma performs density functional theory calculations to predict structure and energetics that support and guide the experimental studies. Both research programs integrate research and educational components through the training of undergraduate researchers.  This research is carried out by undergraduates at William and Mary and Old Dominion University. Performing independent research helps to teach these students not only the joy of discovery but also how to handle and work through the inevitable failures that accompany real-world science.

In this research, intrinsic gas-phase properties of peptides and their fragments are determined using 1) the extended kinetic method, 2) hydrogen deuterium exchange, 3) infrared multiphoton dissociation spectroscopy, 4) peptide fragmentation studies and 5) density functional computations. The ultimate goals of these studies are to establish the relationship between amino acid structure and thermochemical properties, to better understand the effects of intramolecular hydrogen bonding on the gas-phase chemistry of amino acids and peptides, and to explain the mechanisms for selective fragmentations in low-energy tandem mass spectrometry experiments. This detailed knowledge may be integrated into peptide sequencing methods so that they can better account for the presence of unusual amino acids, and for selective fragmentations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit.

The goal of the proposed research was to further our understanding of the fundamental mechanisms of and energetic requirements for peptide fragmentation experiments in tandem mass spectrometers (MS). These experiments form the basis of MS-based proteomics experiments aimed at an enhanced knowledge of the behavior of proteins. Though highly automated, these MS-based proteomics experiments rely on empirically-derived "rules" for how peptides fall apart in mass spectrometers. Our goal is to improve our understanding of these "rules" so as to better predict when they will fail. During the four year term of the award, we published four papers on the structure and energetics of small organic, inorganic, and biologically-relevant molecules.

Our first paper utilized IRMPD spectroscopy to show that the AO b2+ ion from dissociation of the peptide AOAA and the AAO b3+ ion from dissociation of the AAOA peptide have novel lactam structures (JASMS 2019, 20, 1565.). Many peptides form bn+ ions when dissociated and our group, in collaboration with Vicki Wysocki’s group at Ohio State, have been systematically studying the structure of bn+ ions using IRMPD at the FELIX free electron facility in Nijmegen, Netherlands. Most bn+ ions have either protonated oxazolone structures or diketopiperazine/macrocylic structures depending on the nature of the amino acids that comprise the ion. We showed that the lysine analog ornithine (R=CH2CH2CH2NH2) leads to a novel lactam structure when it is the terminal residue in the bn+ ions that we studied (Figure 1).

Our second paper was a collaborative study with Alex Kandel at Notre Dame in which we continued our study of the gas-phase structure of multimers of small molecule pharmaceuticals (JPC-C, 2020 124, 5213.). Most pharmaceuticals can crystalize in several different forms, but typically only one of these is pharmaceutically active. Our collaborators use scanning tunneling microscopy to study the self-assembly of small drug molecules deposited on surfaces. In our most recent study, they showed that the drug carbamazepine forms “magic” number tetramers when deposited on to surfaces (Figure 2). We confirmed that this drug also forms magic number clusters in the gas-phase using electrospray ionization (Figure 3). Interestingly, a related molecule dibenzazepine does not form magic number clusters due to differences in intramolecular hydrogen bonding capabilities. Though not directly related to peptide sequencing, this study ties in nicely with our continued effort to understand the role of hydrogen bonding in determining the structure of various classes of molecules.

 

Our third paper arose from a collaboration with the Shuman/Viggiano group at the Air Force Research Lab (JPC-A. 2022, 10, 1648). In an earlier study, we showed that the reaction rates of small aluminum clusters with atomic oxygen track the electron affinities of the neutral aluminum clusters obtained from photoelectron spectroscopy measurements. In this study, our group calculated the electron affinities of a series of aluminum hydride (Al­n­H­) clusters using CCSD(T) methods. We showed that the electron affinities for clusters follow an even-odd alternation in electron affinity (Figure 4) and that the experimental activation energies for reaction with oxygen track the EAs for clusters with n ≥ 9 (Figure 5). This study is another example of our goals of an enhanced understanding of the subtle interplay between structure and energetics in gas-phase ions.

 

Finally, we completed a study of the acid-base properties of a series of methylated cysteine and serine analogs in collaboration with Professor Matthew Hartman at VCU (IJMS 2022, 475, 116833.). The Hartman group has developed a novel method for incorporation of unusual amino acids into small peptides for peptide drug development applications. We measured the gas-phase acid-base properties of a-methylated and gem-dimethylated serine and cysteine, all of which have been incorporated into peptides by the Hartman group.  For these studies, we used the extended kinetic method in a triple quadrupole instrument. We showed that methylation increases the basicity of these analogs over their non-methylated counterparts, but has a smaller effect on the acidity. Interestingly, density functional theory and MP2 calculations predict that the most acidic site of the methylated cysteine analogs is the thiol group rather than the COOH (Figure 6). Acid-base properties of peptides are directly influenced by the properties of the constituent amino acids and they ultimately control the peptide fragmentation process through the mobile proton model.

Broader Impacts

The main function of a primarily undergraduate chemistry departments is the preparation of future generations of scientists. At William and Mary, this charge is accomplished through both classroom teaching and undergraduate research. During the award period, twenty W&M undergrads and 3 W&M Master’s students worked on projects related to the proposal. Over half of these students were female and three were a members of traditionally underrepresented groups. Undergraduate research helps to teach these students not only the joy of discovery but also how to handle and work though the inevitable failures that accompany professional endeavors.


Last Modified: 12/19/2022
Modified by: John C Poutsma
